text: - --regular ones.

Yeah, we're
happy that you won.
I'll go behind him.

About "Galaxy Quest"
and stuff like that.
Just about.
Are you guys fans of "Moon?"

That's a great movie.
- He was really good in "Moon."

- He was really good in "Moon."
- I was very--

- Do we field the questions?
- On his own, right?
[LAUGHTER]

Question in the back,
question in the back.
Mike Schneider from IndieWire.
What up?

Couldn't help but notice
there's a lot of hair on these
faces up there.

Is this a solidarity
thing, or is it

just a weird
coincidence that you
all are hairy at the same time?
I think it's just depression.
Yeah.

When actors don't work, they
very quickly get depressed.

- Yes.
- Yeah.

And we grow beards
three times as fast.
Exactly.

This is my first
beard, actually,
and I'm very proud of it.
It's great.

And usually when
we're not doing "Veep,"

we play kind of
musty characters.

My beard is all
makeup, though.
This is not real.

I just put this on
for award shows.

Yeah.
- Very good.
Can you guys talk about--

I know there's been some
discussion about the show
might return in August.

What is the update on when
you go back into production?
Last I heard, it was August.

We're coming back in August.
Yes.
Well, we're starting shooting.

We're starting
shooting in August.

We're starting
shooting in August.
Yeah.

Episode one will be
done shooting by October.
That's right.
Yeah.
[LAUGHTER]
And airing in '22, right?

- [LAUGHS]
- Yeah, airing in '22.

Because HBO's kind of
locked up with stuff.
Hi, Russ from Hollywood Life.

Do you know how you want
your characters to end,

or are you just leaving
it to the writers?

Would you be OK--
obviously, you're
OK with the writers and stuff.
But--

Yeah, I'd like to jump
off a ledge, really drunk.
One way.
Just like--

It's all been
leading up to it.
Yeah.

I'd like to work into
"Game of Thrones" somehow.

- A time machine.
- Yeah.

I think Furlong
should become president.
It would be pretty impressive.

- Pretty impressive.
- Yeah, it would.

Yeah, he'd be good.
- And I'll cover it.

Right?
I'll cover it.
Sounds good.

I'll cover it on all
networks all the time.
Yes.
It would be like Abel--

He should be
ambassador to NATO.

I think that's the
only path for me.
Yeah.
Yes, for NATO.
Clea, what are you doing?

- Clea, are your--
- Come on up here.

- Clea.
- Get up here.

- Get up here.
- Hold on.

Do you have a question
for us or something?
Hi.

We'll answer all your Sam
Rockwell-related questions.
[INAUDIBLE]

You look too good
to be back there.

Come on, buddy.
- Come on.
We need some glam up here.
Next question over right here.
Go ahead.
Hi, Jeannie Wolf.

I just want to hear how you've
been in touch with Julia.
Has anyone called her tonight?
I mean, I know it just happened.
And a report on how she's doing?

The cell service,
actually, in the thing
is actually pretty terrible.
It's pretty terrible.

And I left my
cellphone at the table,

so I've got to remember
to pick that up.
Mine too.

It's just a mental note that I
need to remember to pick it up.

Mine's like
right on the table.

I just lost a phone.
- Me as well.

We wouldn't be
here without her.
Yeah.

We wouldn't be
here without her.

She's--
- It's true.
Yeah.

But we were all texting
earlier today as well.

Yeah, we were all
texting today and--
Her strength is extraordinary.

We haven't since we
started this, I don't think.
No.
Yeah.

She's generally been in good
spirits when we've seen her.

She has a good sense of humor,
which I think will carry her

along, which I think does
wonders if you're going
through something like this.

So I mean, she's
incredibly strong,

and she's sort of uniquely able
to combat something like this.
I mean, she's incredible.
Yeah.
Yeah.
Well, wish she was here.

- Yeah.
- Yes, we all wish she was here.
Very much.
We do too.

And also, my phone
is at the table,
and I just-- guys, help me out.

I don't want to forget that.
- I know.

Thank you.
OK.
Where is it?

The people from "Glow"
are going to steal it.

- Hi back here.
- Wad of cash you left.
Maureen with EW.
This question's for Tony.

I have $60 in cash, and I
just really don't want to--

I know that you
brought your high school

drama teacher with you tonight.
- I did.
I did, yeah.

And I just wondered
if you could talk

a little bit about
what that meant to you
and why you wanted to do that.
Yeah.
So Tina Williams was--

I was so thankful to be
able to bring her tonight.

In Tallahassee, Florida, she
started this children's theater

when I was in-- well,
she started way before,

but when I was in middle school,
I was having a hard time.

I wasn't into sports,
and then my parents
got me into this theater.
And it just changed my life.

So I'm incredibly grateful
to her, and for her

to be able to experience this
is like a gift to me and to her.
So it's pretty awesome.

It's kind of like an "F you"
to your sports teachers, too.
Yeah.

And it's kind of an "F
you" to my sports teacher.

It is, it is.
- Exactly.
You're [INAUDIBLE].
And I hope they hear that.
I'm-- hold on just one second.

Sports teachers?
- Yeah, of course.

I don't think there
are sports teachers.

There's been a lot
of teaching afoot.

There's football teacher, your
basketball teacher, all those.

You know.
- It's true.

- Your [INAUDIBLE] teacher.
- That's what I called them.
[LAUGHTER]
Your English coach.
[LAUGHS]

Rehearsal [INAUDIBLE]
sports all the time.

I had a football teacher--
- Am I next?
Hi, guys.

I'm Taylor with
"New York Magazine."

Congrats.
- Hi.
Thank you.

Can you guys talk a little
bit about how Julia is such

a leader when the
cameras aren't rolling

and how her
leadership has really

evolved throughout
all these years
you've been doing the show?

All of us were kind
of a bunch of divas
when we started "Veep."

But she doesn't have a bad
day, so nobody can misbehave.

- Yeah.
- She's the best.

Yeah, and it's also whoever's
number one on the call shoot,
she sets the tone.

And she has just set
a tone for everybody.
It's a team.
We're all a part of a team.
Nobody's walking on eggshells.
Everybody can throw in jokes.

She has no arrogance,
no entitlement.
Great collaborator.
Great collaborator.

And it really creates this
environment that's a family.

And that's what-- because
all that other stuff,

entitlement and arrogance, just
sucks creativity out of a room.
And one hell of a cook!

- And she's a really good cook.
- She's very smart.

[INAUDIBLE] impressed
with her, too,

that she would show up
to scenes that she's not
in to get behind the monitor.

And that's something I feel like
you don't often see people--

when they're not there,
they're not there.

But she was there when
she wasn't supposed to be.
Yeah.
What's her best dish?
Oh, uh, key lime pie.

She makes a really
good key lime pie.
Wow.
And chocolate chip cookie.
And chocolate chip cookie.
I got a glass of water or two.
We miss her greatly here.
We wish she were here, big time.

- Best dish she's a good chef.
- Yeah.

- And just again--
- Hi, guys!
--I left my phone on the--
Hey, congratulations.

I'm a huge fan, so
I have to say that.

So I'm personally
curious how much of what

you guys do is improvisation
versus scripted.
Sam.

Tricky line to
learn [INAUDIBLE]..

(LAUGHING) I think any of
us could answer this question.
[LAUGHTER]

So the way that kind of the
process for "Veep" works

is that we do rehearsals with a
script, and then we put aside--

and some of the improv that we
do in rehearsal kind of gets
worked into the script.

But by the time we're on
set, it's all scripted.
The script.

But it has, like, some
of our personal stuff

that we've worked
through in the script.

But it's all pretty much
scripted, like a hundo.

- And I will say that the more--
- [INAUDIBLE] motel.

The more that
we've been on set,

the more we'll ask for
forgiveness rather than
permission to try something.
Yes, that is the thing.
Don't forget your phone!

Thank you.
Thank you.

It's on the table.
- Oh, that's right.
I don't want to forget it.
Thank you.
$60 cash up for the grabs.

But I also feel like,
too, there's an energy
of not making it sound written.

I think it [INAUDIBLE]
feel very conversational
and working it out.
That's what Julia will do.

She'll come in when
she's not doing a scene,

and she'll watch the
monitors and say,

dirty it up, dirty it up.
- Zhuzh it.
Yeah, zhuzh it.
It was called zhuzhing.

So you're always
on top of each other,

and throwing stuff
around, and making it

seem like it's not
(SNOOTY VOICE) rehearsed.
Mm-hm.

And then there are
also alts that come in.

So they have the script
as it is, and then

a new joke will fly
in, you'll do the joke,

and so it feels
real fresh and new.
Gary Cole gets the worst alts.
[LAUGHTER]

Because he always has
really incredibly hard

things to say that just come
out of nowhere, like, you know,
the--

90% of what I say, I
don't know what it means.
[LAUGHTER]

The atomic number for
hydrogen or something.

And they just throw this
stuff at him when we get
our takes printed or whatever.
And I don't know how he does it.

Conversely, I
get the best alts.
Yes.

They're very short
and vulgar every time.
Yes.
Mine are pretty vulgar, too.
In which orifice?
[LAUGHTER]
And Jane McCabe--
Jane McCabe has some nasty--

--character for this time of
sexual harassment in the news
media and everywhere else.
She was extraordinary.

[INAUDIBLE] writers, too,
is give women a chance

to play all kinds of people
and even the predatory,

sexual harassment
kind of bosses.

- Yeah.
- Mm-hm.

So it's kind of way ahead
of its time for 12 months.
[LAUGHTER]
And I love playing it.

- Thank you guys so much.
- Thank you, guys.
Thank you.
Thank you, guys.

Not a single Sam
Rockwell question.
[LAUGHTER]
